Legal_Issue: Whether the Pelican Lake Appeal Board's decision to dismiss the election appeal without a hearing was procedurally fair
Application_Facts: The Board had only four members instead of five and allowed CEO and DRO representations at the initial stage, breaching procedural fairness
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the judicial review, setting aside the Board's decision
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Court_Ruling: Decision set aside and remitted to a properly constituted Board
Defendant_Behavior: Board proceeded with fewer than required members and allowed improper participation by CEO and DRO
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural irregularities in the composition and process of the Appeal Board
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, including opportunity for rebuttal
Assessment_Factor: Number of Board members, impartiality, opportunity to be heard
Procedural_Issue: Board lacked quorum (only four members instead of five) and failed to ensure impartial process
Legal_Provision_Cited: Requirements for five impartial members and procedural fairness under the Pelican Lake Election Act
Application_Basis: Appeal dismissed without hearing due to lack of proper board constitution
Relief_Sought: Setting aside the Board’s decision and remitting for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: An election appeal requires five impartial members and adherence to procedural fairness
Harm_Assessment: Applicants denied fair hearing on election appeal
Cause_Description: Applicants appealed dismissal of their election appeal due to procedural irregularities
Legal_Provision_Violated: Pelican Lake Election Act – quorum and procedural fairness requirements
Decision_Rationale: Failure to meet statutory quorum and procedural fairness rendered the decision invalid
